label: BraTS'17: Data Request
description: Please fill in the following details to request the data from BraTS 2017 challenge. (https://www.med.upenn.edu/sbia/brats2017.html).

experimentName.label: Single Word Team Name (this will show up in the leaderboard)
experimentName.help: A single word teamname is required.

institutionalEmail.label: Institutional Email
institutionalEmail.help: Irrespective to the email used for your ipp account, you need to use an institutional email address here.

affiliation.label: Affiliation(s)/Institution(s)
affiliation.help: Please write all institutions and departments involved in your team.

role.label: Role
role.help: e.g.: Undergraduate, Postgraduate, PhD student, Postdoc, Assistant Professor.

label: BraTS'17 Testing Data: Segmentation Task
description: Please note that in order to be able to evaluate your segmentation labels and be included in the leaderboard display you must be registered for the challenge via the BraTS 2017 website (https://www.med.upenn.edu/sbia/brats2017.html) using the same email address as the one you used to register in this portal.

experimentName.label: Experiment description.
experimentName.help: We strongly suggest use of this space to define the method/parameters you used to produce your segmentation labels. This will be incredibly useful if you intend to make multiple submissions and optimize your method accordingly.

segmentationLabels.label: Segmentation Labels of Testing Data
segmentationLabels.help: Use this section to upload your actual segmentation labels in .nii.gz format. Note that each file should be named using the patient ID, given by the folder name containing the 4 modalities for each patient. In other words, you were given files called ID_t1.nii.gz, ID_t2.nii.gz, etc. Please upload segmentations called ID.nii.gz

label: BraTS'17 Testing Data: Survival Task
description: Please note that in order to be able to evaluate your survival predictions and be included in the leaderboard display you must be registered for the challenge via the BraTS 2017 website (https://www.med.upenn.edu/sbia/brats2017.html) using the same email address as the one you used to register in this portal.

experimentName.label: Experiment description.
experimentName.help: We strongly suggest use of this space to define the method/parameters you used to produce your predicted survival values. This will be incredibly useful if you intend to make multiple submissions and optimize your method accordingly.

inputSheet.label: Predicted Survival Values of Testing Data
inputSheet.help: Use this section to upload a .CSV of predicted survival values. The csv should NOT contain ANY HEADER, but only the subject IDs in the first column, and the survival in days in the second.

label: BraTS'18: Data Request
description:
Please fill out the following details to request a link to the BraTS 2018 training and validation data. You will receive a notification when the request is processed. Detailed instructions can be found at https://www.med.upenn.edu/sbia/brats2018.html. Note: If you have previously requested the data and need the link again, please simply fill out the form again and you will receive the same information.

Note: If you have previously requested the data and need the link again, please simply fill out the form again and you will receive the same information.

institutionalEmail.label: Institutional Email
institutionalEmail.help: Irrespective to the email used for your ipp account, you need to use a preferably institutional email address here.

affiliation.help: Please write all institutions and departments involved in your team.

Note: If you have previously requested the data and need the link again, please simply fill out the form again and you will receive the same information.

experimentName.label: Team Name (Single word without spaces; This is the name that will show up in the leaderboards)
experimentName.help: A single word teamname is required.

institutionalEmail.label: Institutional Email
institutionalEmail.help: Irrespective to the email used for your ipp account, you need to use a preferably institutional email address here.

affiliation.label: Affiliation(s)/Institution(s)
affiliation.help: Please write all institutions and departments involved in your team.

role.label: Role
role.help: e.g.: Undergraduate, PhD student, Postdoc, Assistant Professor.

label: BraTS'19 Testing Data: Segmentation Task
description: Please note that in order to be able to evaluate your segmentation labels and be included in the leaderboard display, you must be first registered for the challenge through the \"BraTS'19 Data Request\" application in the CBICA Image Processing Portal using the same email address as the one you used to register in this portal.

experimentName.label: Experiment description.
experimentName.help: We strongly suggest use of this space to define the method/parameters you used to produce your segmentation labels. This will be incredibly useful if you intend to make multiple submissions and optimize your method accordingly.

segmentationLabels.label: Segmentation Labels of Testing Data (Note: These uploaded files are kept by the IPP for future reference and evaluation within the scope of the BraTS challenge.)
segmentationLabels.help: Use this section to upload your segmentation labels in .nii.gz format. Note that each file should be named using the patient ID, given by the folder name containing the 4 modalities for each patient. In other words, for subjects that you were given files named ID_t1.nii.gz, ID_t2.nii.gz, etc., the uploaded segmenations should be named ID.nii.gz

label: BraTS'19 Testing Data: Survival Task
description: Please note that in order to be able to evaluate your segmentation labels and be included in the leaderboard display, you must be first registered for the challenge through the \"BraTS'19 Data Request\" application in the CBICA Image Processing Portal using the same email address as the one you used to register in this portal.

experimentName.label: Experiment description.
experimentName.help: We strongly suggest use of this space to define the method/parameters you used to produce your predicted survival values. This will be incredibly useful if you intend to make multiple submissions and optimize your method accordingly.

inputSheet.label: Predicted Survival Values of Testing Data (Note: These uploaded files are kept by the IPP for future reference and evaluation within the scope of the BraTS challenge.)
inputSheet.help: Use this section to upload a .csv of predicted survival values. The csv should NOT contain ANY HEADER, but only the subject IDs in the first column, and the survival in days in the second.

label: BraTS'19 Testing Data: Uncertainty Task
description: Please note that in order to be able to evaluate, you must be first registered for the challenge through the \"BraTS'19 Data Request\" application in the CBICA Image Processing Portal using the same email address as the one you used to register in this portal.

experimentName.label: Experiment description.
experimentName.help: We strongly suggest use of this space to define the method/parameters you used to produce your segmentation labels. This will be incredibly useful if you intend to make multiple submissions and optimize your method accordingly.

segmentationLabels.label: Segmentation Labels of Testing Data (Note: These uploaded files are kept by the IPP for future reference and evaluation within the scope of the BraTS challenge.)
segmentationLabels.help: Use this section to upload your segmentation labels in .nii.gz format. There should be 4 segmentation maps uploaded per patient ID, having file names ID.nii.gz, ID_unc_whole.nii.gz, ID_unc_core.nii.gz, ID_unc_enhance.nii.gz, respectively.

label: BraTS'20: Data Request
description: Please fill out the following details to request a link to the training data, as well as register your team for the BraTS 2020 challenge. You will receive a notification when the request is processed. Detailed instructions can be found at https://www.med.upenn.edu/cbica/brats2020.html. Note: If you have previously requested the data and need the link again, please simply fill out the form again and you will receive the same information.

experimentName.label: Team Name (Single word without spaces; This is the name that will show up in the leaderboards)
experimentName.help: A single word teamname is required.

institutionalEmail.label: Institutional Email
institutionalEmail.help: Irrespective to the email used for your ipp account, you need to use a preferably institutional email address here.

affiliation.label: Affiliation(s)/Institution(s)
affiliation.help: Please write all institutions and departments involved in your team.

role.label: Role
role.help: e.g.: Undergraduate, PhD student, Postdoc, Assistant Professor.

label: BraTS'20 Testing Data: Segmentation Task
description: Please note that in order to be able to evaluate your segmentation labels and be included in the leaderboard display, you must be first registered for the challenge through the \"BraTS'20 Data Request\" application in the CBICA Image Processing Portal using the same email address as the one you used to register in this portal.

experimentName.label: Experiment description.
experimentName.help: We strongly suggest use of this space to define the method/parameters you used to produce your segmentation labels. This will be incredibly useful if you intend to make multiple submissions and optimize your method accordingly.

segmentationLabels.label: Segmentation Labels of Testing Data (Note: These uploaded files are kept by the IPP for future reference and evaluation within the scope of the BraTS challenge.)
segmentationLabels.help: Use this section to upload your segmentation labels in .nii.gz format. Note that each file should be named using the patient ID, given by the folder name containing the 4 modalities for each patient. In other words, for subjects that you were given files named ID_t1.nii.gz, ID_t2.nii.gz, etc., the uploaded segmenations should be named ID.nii.gz. Make sure to match the origin of your segmentations to the provided data.

inputSheet.label: Predicted Survival Values of Validation Data (Note: These uploaded files are kept by the IPP for future reference and evaluation within the scope of the BraTS challenge.)
inputSheet.help: Use this section to upload a .csv of predicted survival values. The csv should NOT contain ANY HEADER, but only the subject IDs in the first column, and the survival in days in the second.

label: BraTS'20 Validation Data: Uncertainty Task
description: Please note that in order to be able to evaluate, you must be first registered for the challenge through the \"BraTS'20 Data Request\" application in the CBICA Image Processing Portal using the same email address as the one you used to register in this portal.

experimentName.label: Experiment description.
experimentName.help: We strongly suggest use of this space to define the method/parameters you used to produce your segmentation labels. This will be incredibly useful if you intend to make multiple submissions and optimize your method accordingly.

segmentationLabels.label: Segmentation Labels of Validation Data (Note: These uploaded files are kept by the IPP for future reference and evaluation within the scope of the BraTS challenge.)
segmentationLabels.help: Use this section to upload your segmentation labels in .nii.gz format. There should be 4 segmentation maps uploaded per patient ID, having file names ID.nii.gz, ID_unc_whole.nii.gz, ID_unc_core.nii.gz, ID_unc_enhance.nii.gz, respectively.

label: MICCAI BraTS 2017 Training Phase: All evaluation applications will be available shortly.
description:
We appreciate your interest in the International Multimodal Brain Tumor Segmentation Challenge 2017.
Please note that we are currently optimizing all the evaluation applications and the leaderboard display. Once everything is ready all participants registered for the challenge via the BraTS 2017 website (https://www.med.upenn.edu/sbia/brats2017.html) will receive email notifications.

experimentName.label: Here you will be entering your team's name.

subjectList.label: List of subjects
subjectList.help: Here you will be uploading a spreadsheet (.csv) of subjects that you want to evaluate their segmentations.

segmentationLabels.label: Segmentation Labels
segmentationLabels.help: Here you will be uploading the actual segmentation labels in .nii.gz format.

label: CaPTk Bias Correction
description:
This job runs bias correction algorithms on an image using CaPTk tools.


$Revision$

mask.label: Image Mask
mask.help: Mask for the input image in .nii.gz format (NIfTI)

correctionType.label: Indicate which bias correction algorithm to use

splineOrder.label: The spline order for bias correction (defaults to 3)

filterNoise.label: The filter noise level for bias correction (defaults to 0.010000)

biasBins.label: If no mask is specified, the number of histogram bins for Otsu used for mask generation (defaults to 3)

fittingLevels.label: The number of fitting levels to use for bias correction (defaults to 4)

maxIterations.label: Maximum number of iterations for bias correction (defaults to 100)

fwhm.label: The filter noise level for bias correction (defaults to 0.150000)

label: CaPTk BraTS Preprocessing Pipeline
description:
This job runs the full BraTS preprocessing pipeline using CaPTk tools.


$Revision$

t1ceImage.label: T1CE Image
t1ceImage.help: Input structural T1-weighted post-contrast image (DICOM or NIfTI)

t1Image.label: T1 Image
t1Image.help: Input structural T1-weighted pre-contrast image (DICOM or NIfTI)

t2Image.label: T2 Image
t2Image.help: Input structural T2-weighted contrast image (DICOM or NIfTI)

flImage.label: FLAIR Image
flImage.help: Input structural FLAIR contrast image (DICOM or NIfTI)

skullStrip.label: Indicate whether to strip skulls from input (defaults to True)

brainTumor.label: Indicate whether to segment brain tumors (defaults to True)

label: CaPTk Diffusion Derivatives
description:
This job calculates diffusion derivatives of the input DWI image using the CaPTk DiffusionDerivatives tool.


$Revision$

input.label: Input DWI File
input.help: This is the NIfTI (.nii.gz) image from which diffusion derivatives will be calculated.

mask.label: Mask File
mask.help: Mask file in NIfTI format (.nii.gz) outlining the region of interest.

Bval.label: Bval File
Bval.help: This bval file is needed to calculate diffusion derivatives.

Bvec.label: Bvec file
Bvec.help: This bvec file is needed to calculate diffusion derivatives.

axial.label: Indicate whether to generate the axial diffusivity image (defaults to True)

choices.0: do not generate the axial diffusivity image

fractional.label: Indicate whether to generate the fractional anisotropy image (defaults to True)

choices.0: do not generate the fractional anisotropy image

radial.label: Indicate whether to generate the radial diffusivity image (defaults to True)

choices.0: do not generate the radial diffusivity image

coefficient.label: Indicate whether to generate apparent diffusion coefficient image (defaults to True)

choices.1: generate the apparent diffusion coefficient image
choices.0: do not generate the apparent diffusion coefficient image

label: CaPTk Histogram Matching
description:
This job runs the Histogram Matching preprocessing algorithm on an image using CaPTk tools.


$Revision$

matchImage.label: Image to Match
matchImage.help: Image to match to, in .nii.gz format (NIfTI)

matchBins.label: Number of histogram bins for histogram matching (defaults to 100)

matchQnts.label: Number of quantile values to match for histogram matching (defaults to 40)

label: CaPTk Image Registration
description:
This job registers moving images with a fixed image using CaPTk preprocessing tools.


$Revision$

maskImage.label: Mask Image
maskImage.help: Mask file (.nii.gz) indicating region to register

registration.label: Registration Type
registration.help: Valid values: Affine, Deformable, Rigid. You can also specify Affine-DOF where DOF is the number of degrees of freedom, e.g. Affine-12 for 12 degrees of freedom. Defaults to Affine.

regMetrics.label: Registration Metrics
regMetrics.help: Valid values: SSD (Sum of Squared Differences), MI (Mutual Information), NMI (Normalized Mutual Information), or NCC-AxBxC (Normalized cross correlation where A, B and C are integer radii). Defaults to NMI.

regNoIters.label: Number of iterations per multi-res level
regNoIters.help: Format: N1,N2,N3 where N1, N2 and N3 are integers. Default: 100,50,5

regSegMoving.label: Indicate if moving image is a segmentation file
regSegMoving.help: True if the moving image is a segmentation file, false otherwise. If true, nearest-label interpolation is applied. Default: false

choices.1: moving image is a segmentation file
choices.0: moving image is an image file

label: CaPTk Perfusion Derivatives
description:
This job calculates perfusion derivatives of the input image using the CaPTk PerfusionDerivatives tool.


$Revision$

input.label: Input DSC-MRI Image
input.help: Input DSC-MRI image in NIfTI format (.nii.gz) from which to extract perfusion derivatives.

PSR.label: Indicate whether to generate the Percent Signal Recovery (PSR) image (defaults to True)

choices.0: do not generate the PSR image

peakHeight.label: Indicate whether to generate the Peak Height image (defaults to True)

choices.0: do not generate the peak height image

apRCBV.label: Indicate whether to extract the automatically-extraction proxy to relative cerebral volume (apRCBV) image (defaults to True)

choices.0: do not generate the apRCBV image

label: CaPTk SUSAN Denoising
description:
This job runs the SUSAN denoising algorithm on an image using CaPTk tools.


$Revision$

susanThresh.label: Susan smoothing Intensity Variation Threshold value (defaults to 80.00000)

label: CaPTk Z-Score Normalization
description:
This job runs the Z-Score Normalization algorithm on an image using CaPTk tools.


$Revision$

normQuant.label: The Lower-Upper quantile range to remove (ex. 5,95)

normCut.label: The Lower-Upper Cut-off (multiple of standard deviation) to remove (ex. 3,3)

label: COMPARE: Classification Of Morphological Patterns using Adaptive Regional Elements
description:
COMPARE Web page


This software requires two groups of images (feature maps), one for patients and the other for controls.
The main output is a text file with classification results.

experimentName.label: Provide a name for your experiment

group1files.help: List of image files of group1 (will be labelled as +1)
group1files.label: List of Image Files of Group1

group2files.help: List of image files of group2 (will be labelled as -1)
group2files.label: List of Image Files of Group2

k.help: std value for Gaussian kernel in SVM (range:1~10000. This value is multiplied by 100! default:1)
k.label: kernelwidth

j.help: searching range for std value (should be greater than above value, optional)
j.label: kernelwidthbig

s.help: Gaussian kernel size for smoothing score map (default: 3.0, range:1~10)
s.label: skernelwidth

n.help: searching space of feature number (range:1~1500, default: 150)
n.label: nsearchingspace

testingsfiles.help: List of image files of testing group
testingsfiles.label: testingfiles

label: DeepBrainNet Age Prediction
description: Pipeline to obtain age prediction from T1 MRI scan

label: DRAMMS RAVENS Analysis
description:
DRAMMS RAVENS Web page


DRAMMS - Deformable Registration via Attribute Matching and Mutual-Saliency Weighting
This is suitable if you have no deformation yet. This requires only two input images, and the label map in the source image space. From these, users may want to calculate the RAVENS maps in one step.
Please note: the registered image is in the source space and the RAVENS maps are in the target space.

experimentName.label: Provide a name for your experiment

subjectImage1.label: Subject Image 1
subjectImage1.help: Subject image, type NIFTi or ANALYZE

subjectImage2.label: Segmented Image
subjectImage2.help: Segmented image, type NIFTi or ANALYZE

templateImage.label: Template Image
templateImage.help: Template image, type NIFTi or ANALYZE

labelRegions.label: Regions to label
labelRegions.help: This argument specifies the labels of the regions (defined in the supplied Segmented Image file) in which RAVENS maps will be calculated. For example, '10,150,150' results in the computation of three RAVENS maps, one for each region labeled by 10, 150, 250 in the supplied segmented image. Up to 5 labels can be specified at a time.

label: FeTS'21: Registration and Data Request
description: Please fill out the following details to register for the FeTS 2021 challenge. You will receive a notification when the request is processed.

experimentName.label: Team Name (Single word. This is the name that will appear in the leaderboards)
experimentName.help: A single word teamname is required, and any spaces will be automatically replaced with an underscore. Please try to pick a name that is unique to your team as you will not be able to register if the teamname overlaps with another existing registration.

institutionalEmail.label: Institutional Email
institutionalEmail.help: Irrespective to the email used for your ipp account, an institutional (either academic, or industrial) email address is required for registration.

affiliation.label: Main Affiliation
affiliation.help: Please enter the institution of your main affiliation for your team.

researchGroup.label: Research Group/Lab Name
researchGroup.help: Please enter the name of your Research Group/Lab.

role.label: Role
role.help: e.g.: Undergraduate, PhD student, Postdoc, Assistant Professor.

declaration.label: By clicking the Submit button below, I declare that I do not intend to perform any malicious activities on machines where my submitted application is executed.

label: GLISTR
description: GLISTR: Glioma Image Segmentation and Registration Version 3.1.0 Copyright (c) 2014 University of Pennsylvania. All rights reserved. See http://www.cbica.upenn.edu/sbia/software/license.html DEPRECATED

experimentDescription.label: Experiment Description (optional)
experimentDescription.help: We strongly suggest use of this space to make it recognizable for you. This will be incredibly useful if you intend to make multiple submissions.

images.label: Required images (.nii.gz)
images.help:
GLISTR requires 4 images:
T1 image - describes the subject's native T1-weighted MRI volume
T2 image - describes the subject's native T2-weighted MRI volume
T1CE image - describes the subject's post-contrast (contrast-enhanced) T1-weighted MRI volume
FLAIR image - describes the subject's T2 Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) MRI volume

seedFile.label: Tumor seedpoint file
seedFile.help: This is a .txt file that specifies tumor location and radius to roughly approximate its volume. We have developed 'BrainTumorViewer' (https://www.cbica.upenn.edu/sbia/software/braintumorviewer/) specifically for creating this file. However, you can use any software you want in order to create it as long as it is saved in the very same structure. More information on the exact structure of the file can be found in the pages of GLISTR (https://www.cbica.upenn.edu/sbia/software/glistr/manual.html).

pointFile.label: Tissue seedpoint file
pointFile.help: This is a .txt file that specifies coordinates (x,y,z) used to model the intensity distribution of each tissue type under segmentation. We have developed 'BrainTumorViewer' (https://www.cbica.upenn.edu/sbia/software/braintumorviewer/) specifically for creating this file. However, you can use any software you want in order to create it as long as it is saved in the very same structure. More information on the exact structure of the file can be found in the pages of GLISTR (https://www.cbica.upenn.edu/sbia/software/glistr/manual.html).

label: GLISTRboost: Brain Tumor Segmentation (BRATS'15 winning method)
description:
This application runs our method proposed for segmenting low- and high-grade gliomas in multimodal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) volumes.
Note that this is the winning method of the Multimodal Brain Tumor Image Segmentation (BRATS) Challenge, held in conjunction with the Medical Image Computing and Computer Assisted Intervention (MICCAI) conference in Technische Universitaet Muenchen (TUM) in Munich (Germany) - October 2015.
The proposed approach is based on a hybrid generative-discriminative model. Firstly, a generative approach of a joint segmentation-registration scheme based on an Expectation-Maximization framework, that incorporates a glioma growth model, is used to segment the brain scans into tumor and healthy tissue labels. Secondly, a discriminative, gradient boosting multi-class classification, scheme is used to refine tumor labels based on information from multiple patients. Lastly, a probabilistic Bayesian strategy is employed to further refine and finalize the tumor segmentation based on patient-specific intensity statistics from the multiple modalities.

Assumptions: All input MRI volumes (i.e. T1, T1-Gad, T2, T2-FLAIR) must be skull-stripped, resampled to 1mm^3, co-registered and in the LPS coordinate system, for the method to produce meaningful results.

References: Please cite the following publications when using data produced by the hereby application:
- Spyridon Bakas, Ke Zeng, Aristeidis Sotiras, Saima Rathore, Hamed Akbari, Bilwaj Gaonkar, Martin Rozycki, Sarthak Pati, Christos Davatzikos, "GLISTRboost: Combining Multimodal MRI Segmentation, Registration, and Biophysical Tumor Growth Modeling with Gradient Boosting Machines for Glioma Segmentation", Brainlesion: Glioma, Multiple Sclerosis, Stroke and Traumatic Brain Injuries, Springer, LNCS, 9556:144-155, 2016. DOI: 10.1007/978-3-319-30858-6_13
- Spyridon Bakas, Ke Zeng, Aristeidis Sotiras, Saima Rathore, Hamed Akbari, Bilwaj Gaonkar, Martin Rozycki, Sarthak Pati, Christos Davatzikos, "Segmentation of Gliomas in Multimodal Magnetic Resonance Imaging Volumes Based on a Hybrid Generative-Discriminative Framework", In Proceedings of the Multimodal Brain Tumor Image Segmentation Challenge held in conjunction with MICCAI 2015 (MICCAI-BRATS 2015), Technische Universität München (T.U.M.), Munich, Germany, 5-9 Oct 2015

experimentName.label: Provide a name for your experiment (used for tracking its progress).

imageT1.label: T1 Image
imageT1.help: This describes the subject's native T1-weighted MRI volume. Note that this must be skull-stripped, co-registered with the other modalities and oriented Right-to-Left,Anterior-to-Posterior,Inferior-to-Superior.

imageT2.label: T2 Image
imageT2.help: This describes the subject's native T2-weighted MRI volume. Note that this must be skull-stripped, co-registered with the other modalities and oriented Right-to-Left,Anterior-to-Posterior,Inferior-to-Superior.

imageT1gad.label: T1-Gad Image
imageT1gad.help: This describes the subject's post-contrast (contrast-enhanced) T1-weighted MRI volume. Note that this must be skull-stripped, co-registered with the other modalities and oriented Right-to-Left,Anterior-to-Posterior,Inferior-to-Superior.

imageFlair.label: T2-FLAIR Image
imageFlair.help: This describes the subject's T2 Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) MRI volume. Note that this must be skull-stripped, co-registered with the other modalities and oriented Right-to-Left,Anterior-to-Posterior,Inferior-to-Superior.

seedFile.label: Tumor seedpoint file
seedFile.help: This is a .txt file that specifies tumor location and radius to roughly approximate its volume. We have developed 'BrainTumorViewer' (https://www.cbica.upenn.edu/sbia/software/braintumorviewer/) specifically for creating this file. However, you can use any software you want in order to create it as long as it is saved in the very same structure. More information on the exact structure of the file can be found in the pages of GLISTR (https://www.cbica.upenn.edu/sbia/software/glistr/manual.html).

pointFile.label: Tissue seedpoint file
pointFile.help: This is a .txt file that specifies coordinates (x,y,z) used to model the intensity distribution of each tissue type under segmentation. We have developed 'BrainTumorViewer' (https://www.cbica.upenn.edu/sbia/software/braintumorviewer/) specifically for creating this file. However, you can use any software you want in order to create it as long as it is saved in the very same structure. More information on the exact structure of the file can be found in the pages of GLISTR (https://www.cbica.upenn.edu/sbia/software/glistr/manual.html).

label: GraSP: Geodesic graph-based segmentation with shape priors
description:
GraSP web page


GraSP is a graph-based parcellation software. GraSP was initially developed for parcellating the cortex into functionally coherent regions, based on their Pearson correlation.

experimentName.label: Provide a name for your experiment

mask.label: Mask
mask.help: This mask will be parcellated by GraSP. The expected file type is '.nii.gz'

scans.label: Patient images to run GraSP on
scans.help: Patient fmri scans. The expected file type is a 4D '.nii.gz'

k.label: Penalty for introducing a novel parcel
k.help: The higher the penalty, the smaller the number of parcels in the final parcellation.

fr.label: Size of the largest expected parcel.
fr.help: This upper bound is used for speeding up the computation. This value is provided as a fraction of the whole brain.

label: LIBRA: Breast Density Estimation
description:
LIBRA Web page


LIBRA applies an edge-detection algorithm to delineate the boundary of the breast and the boundary of the pectoral muscle. Following the segmentation of the breast, an adaptive multi-class fuzzy c-means algorithm is applied to identify and partition the mammographic breast tissue area, into multiple regions (i.e., clusters) of similar x-ray attenuation. These clusters are then aggregated by a support-vector machine classifier to a final dense tissue area, segmentation. The ratio of the segmented absolute dense area to the total breast area is then used to obtain a measure of breast percent density (PD%).

saveIntermediateFiles.label: To save intermediate files
saveIntermediateFiles.help: Additional files for visualization, debugging and understanding the algorithm step-by-step.

label: MultiSiteSCZClassifier: Healthy-Control/Schizophrenia Binary Classification
description:
This application applies a control/schizophrenia classifier trained on 835 subjects from several global sites on a new subject.
Assumptions: The classifier only requires a skull-stripped t1-image for each subject.

experimentName.label: Provide a name for your experiment (used for tracking its progress).

imageT1.label: T1 Image
imageT1.help: The subject's native T1-weighted MRI volume. Note that this must be skull-stripped and oriented Right-to-Left,Anterior-to-Posterior,Inferior-to-Superior.

Age.label: Age of Subject
Age.help: Please input a value. Integer or float.

Sex.label: Gender of Subject
Sex.help: Please input a value. 0 for male. 1 for female.

label: ODVBA: Optimally-Discriminative Voxel-Based Analysis
description:
ODVBA Web page


ODVBA is used to determine the optimal spatially adaptive smoothing of images, followed by applying a voxel-based group analysis.
The ouput is the p-map file.

experimentName.label: Provide a name for your experiment

controlImages.label: Control images to run ODVBA on
controlImages.help: The images which are used as control. The expected file type is '.nii.gz'

patientImages.label: Patient images to run ODVBA on
patientImages.help: The patient images. The expected file type is '.nii.gz'

numNi.label: Number of neighborhoods to consider
numNi.help: At most, the neighborhood around each non-zero voxel can be considered. Use values between 5000-20000 (default is 10000).

sizeNi.label: Size of neighborhood
sizeNi.help: The neightborhood around each considered voxel. Use values between 9-17 (default is 15).

count.label: Count of voxels in each neighborhood

exponent.label: Exponent phi of discrimination degree
exponent.help: Refer Eq.(11) of MICCAI paper for details. Use values between 0-10 (default is 1).

label: SCPLearn: Identification of Sparse Connectivity Patterns using rsfMRI
description:
SCPLearn Web page


SCPLearn calculates Sparse Connectivity Patterns from rsfMRI Data.
This software requires a list of nifti files, a node definition/atlas nifti file.
Two main outputs are the SCPs in nifti format, and SCP coefficients saved in csv file.

experimentName.label: Provide a name for your experiment

data.help: Resting state fMRI images of Nifti format to generate Sparse Connectivity Patterns from.(min: 1, max: 100)
data.label: Data Files

levels.help: Select if you want hierarchical parcellation
levels.label: Hierarchy

numberOfSCPs.help: This value sets the number of SCPs. Default is 10.
numberOfSCPs.label: Number of SCPs

pruning.help: The pruning threshold as a value between [0,1]. Default = 1
pruning.label: Pruning threshold

label: Structural Processing Pipeline
description:
This would run the structural processing pipeline for T1 images. It includes,

1. Bias Correction ( N4 )

2. Skull-Stripping ( MASS )

3. ROI Segmentation ( MUSE )

4. Tissue segmentation ( MICO )

5. RAVENS maps ( DRAMMS )

You may customize which ones to apply.

experimentName.label: Provide a name for your experiment

subjectImage1.label: Subject Image
subjectImage1.help: Type NIFTi. Providing multiple images will run the chosen pipeline for each image.

runRAVENS.label: Run RAVENS deformations
runRAVENS.help: Outputs one RAVENS maps, normalized, downsampled, and smoothed for each tissue type.

label: BrainMaGe Skull Stripping Pipeline
description:
Brain Mask Generator (BrainMaGe) is a deep learning segmentation algorithm to generate robust and accurate brain masks given any single (or multiple) MR sequences. It has been developed while considering brain MRI scans with apparent abnormalities, such as diffuse gliomas, and its generalizability was evaluated on multi-institutional data of real clinical practice. We expect its novel “modality-agnostic” strategy to contribute in its widespread application on brain MR scans inclusive of apparent tumors, lesions, white matter hyperintensities, as well as healthy brains. Reference: S.Thakur, J.Doshi, S.Pati, S.Rathore, C.Sako, M.Bilello, et al., “Brain extraction on MRI scans in presence of diffuse glioma: Multi-institutional performance evaluation of deep learning methods and robust modality-agnostic training, NeuroImage, 220:117081, 2020. DOI: 10.1016/j.neuroimage.2020.117081


$Revision: 340 $

outputVolumes.label: Indicate whether to output segmented brain volumes in addition to masks (defaults to False)

choices.0: do not output segmented brain volumes

label: Multi Atlas Skull-Stripping (MASS)
description:
MASS Web page


Multi Atlas Skull Stripping (MASS), is a software package designed for robust and accurate brain extraction, applicable for both individual as well as large population studies.


Citation: Jimit Doshi, Guray Erus, Yangming Ou, Bilwaj Gaonkar, Christos Davatzikos, Multi-Atlas Skull-Stripping, Academic Radiology, Volume 20, Issue 12, December 2013, Pages 1566-1576, ISSN 1076-6332, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.acra.2013.09.010. (MASS paper)

subjectImage1.label: Subject Image (LPS oriented)
subjectImage1.help: Type NIFTi. Providing multiple images will run MASS for each image. Bias correcting the input image may yield better results

noCere.label: Indicate whether to use templates with or without cerebellum

numTemp.label: Number of templates to be used for registrations. 1 < regs <=15

regWt.label: Regularization Weight for the DRAMMS registration. 0 < g <= 1

label: MUSE ROI Labeling
description:
MUSE Web page


MUSE is a Multi Atlas ROI Segmentation tool that uses the multi-atlas registration based approach along with intensity weighting to parcellate the given human brain into a set of 153 regions of anatomical interest.


Citation: Jimit Doshi, Guray Erus, Yangming Ou, Susan M. Resnick, Ruben C. Gur, Raquel E. Gur, Theodore D. Satterthwaite, Susan Furth, Christos Davatzikos, MUSE: MUlti-atlas region Segmentation utilizing Ensembles of registration algorithms and parameters, and locally optimal atlas selection, NeuroImage, Volume 127, 15 February 2016, Pages 186-195, ISSN 1053-8119, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2015.11.073. (MUSE paper)

subjectImage1.label: Subject Image (LPS oriented)
subjectImage1.help: Type NIFTi. Providing multiple images will run MUSE for each image. Input image must have LPS orientation, must be bias corrected (N4) and skull-stripped (MASS).

method.label: Registration method(s) to use for registering the templates to the input image

keepRanks.label: Keep the individual Rank Masks generated for each ROI?

noIC.label: Apply Intensity Correction on the probabilities?

noSim.label: Apply Similarity Ranking on the probabilities?

noFuzzy.label: Apply Fuzzy Segmentation of CSF to the probabilities?

noCere.label: Indicate whether to use templates with or without cerebellum

maskWML.label: WML mask (binary) which will be excluded from intensity correction

wtCSF.label: CSF Weight for MICO segmentation used to improve brain/non-brain segmentation

numTemp.label: Number of templates to be used for registrations. 1 < regs <= 35.

regWt.label: Regularization Weight for the DRAMMS registration. 0 < g <= 1.

syn.label: GradStep for greedy symmetric norm diffeomorphic model for ANTS registration. 0 < s <= 1.

label: Sample IPP Job
description:
This job demonstrates some of the features of the IPP and runs just long enough to show various job stages. The job takes various input files (of any type) and performs selected operations.


$Revision: 116 $
$LastChangedDate: 2015-10-26 17:19:09 -0400 (Mon, 26 Oct 2015) $

groundTruth.label: Ground truth
groundTruth.help: A single file, of any type, to be compared in various ways to each of the data files

inputs.label: Data files
inputs.help: One or more of any type of file

operation1.label: Checksum method
operation1.help: Select the method used to produce checksums

operation2.label: Sum of bytes
operation2.help: Produce a sum of the ASCII values of the printable representation of all characters in each input file. This is a completely useless value.

count.label: Number of iterations
count.help: Produce a checksum of this many instances of the file, concatenated together. Default=3

random.label: Apply a random factor
random.help: If chosen, the program will compute a random value and apply it to various calculations in the results.

label: xcpEngine
description:
XCP Engine documentation and development hub


xcpEngine - A multimodal neuroimaging pipeline
xcpEngine - xcpEngine v0.6.0 (ACCELERATOR) is the most recent iteration of the BBL's neuroimage processing system. This system provides a configurable, modular, agnostic, and multimodal platform for neuroimage processing and quality assessment. It implements a number of high-performance denoising approaches and computes regional and voxelwise values of interest for each modality. The system provides a general-purpose image processing interface, as well as a standard toolkit for benchmarking pipeline performance. All pipelines from our 2017 benchmarking paper are implementable, as are the pipelines evaluated in the recent work of Parkes and colleagues. As of v0.6.0, functional and anatomical modalities are supported, with perfusion and diffusion under development.

experimentName.label: Provide a name for your experiment

designFile.help: Design file for the pipeline. Pipelines are configured using parameters in a user-provided design file, which can be readily constructed from a template using the lightweight xcpConfig code. Template designs for anatomical and functional connectivity processing are currently available. More extensive documentation, including examples, can be found at pipedocs.
designFile.label: Design File

cohortFile.help: Cohort file for the pipeline. The cohort file defines the experimental sample, including subject identifiers and input names for each subject. For details and examples, visit the relevant pipedocs page. For processing on IPP, input paths should be stripped of any leading directories; they should include the base name of the file only.
cohortFile.label: Cohort File

cohortInputs.label: Input images and files for processing using xcpEngine
cohortInputs.help: Please select all input images and files listed in the cohort file. The expected file type is '.nii.gz' for single images and '.tar.gz' for processing directories (such as the struc module output or the ANTs Cortical Thickness directory), which should be archived and compressed before processing.

verboseLevel.label: Diagnostics (0: quiet, 1: verbose, 2: more verbose)
verboseLevel.help: If '0' is selected, logs will include only descriptive messages. If '1' is selected, any image processing commands run by the pipeline will be printed explicitly in the log, facilitating error diagnosis. If '2' is selected, image processing commands run by the pipeline and any child commands that they call will be printed explicitly in the log.
